user.description: Create a sensor which tracks consumption of various utilities (e.g., energy, gas, water, heating) over a configured period of time. The utility meter sensor optionally supports splitting the consumption by tariffs, in that case one sensor for each tariff is created as well as a select entity to choose the current tariff and optionally calculating a $$ cost by combining with a price sensor.
user.title: Create an Next Gen Utility Meter

data.tariffs: Tariffs - add a 'total' tariff to track total consumption

predefined.title: Create the Meter using the preefined schedules

data_description.always_available: If activated, the sensor will always show the last known value, even if the source entity is unavailable or unknown.
data_description.delta_values: Enable if the source values are delta values since the last reading instead of absolute values.
data_description.net_consumption: Enable if the source is a net meter, meaning it can both increase and decrease.
data_description.periodically_resetting: Enable if the source may periodically reset to 0, for example at boot of the measuring device. If disabled, new readings are directly recorded after data inavailability.
data_description.remove_calc_sensor: If you do not want to use a calculation sensor, you can remove it here. This will stop showing the attribute values in the Sensor.
data_description.reset_cycle: Select a predefined reset cycle for the meter. This will determine how often the meter resets its values.
data_description.source_calc_sensor: If you want to use a sensor to Calculate a price attribute for the Meter, please select it here. If not selected, the meter will just report the source value.
data_description.tariffs: A list of supported tariffs, leave empty if only a single tariff is needed. If you want to track the total consumption, add a 'total' tariff.
data_description.offset: Offset the day/hour/minute of the meter reset (seconds are ignored atm). This is useful if you want to start the meter on a specific day of the month.
data_description.source_calc_multiplier: If you need to adjust the calculation to match the raw source sensor, you can set the multiplier here. For esxample if your Input Calculator Sensor is $/kWh and your Consumption Sensor is in MW, you would set this to 1000 to get the correct price.
